definition: to take the lead/to gain the upper hand
variant of 占[zhan4]
to observe/to divine
to take possession of/to occupy/to take up
on top/upon/above/upper/previous/first (of multiple parts)/to climb/to get onto/to go up/to attend (class or university)
see 上聲|上声[shang3 sheng1]
wind/news/style/custom/manner/CL:陣|阵[zhen4],絲|丝[si1]

sentences.english: Rational selfinterest is not always the dominating factor.
sentences.chinese: 理性的个体利益不总是占上风的因素。

sentences.english: Money talks way too loud in our country.
sentences.chinese: 在我国，金钱万能太占上风了。

sentences.english: Which scenario will prevail in the months ahead?
sentences.chinese: 今后的几个月哪种结局会占上风？

sentences.english: Until fairly recently, it seemed that Chevron would prevail.
sentences.chinese: 直到最近，似乎雪佛龙公司将占上风。

sentences.english: Force them to speak English and you win.
sentences.chinese: 逼着他们跟你讲英语，你才会占上风。

sentences.english: This cook just happened to be rather ignorant, so he did not mind being cruel when he had the upper hand.
sentences.chinese: 这个厨师恰好无知愚鲁，在占上风时，手下毫不留情。

sentences.english: When we make decisions in advance it's Should that's incharge.
sentences.chinese: 当我们提前做决定时，就是“应该”占上风了。

sentences.english: There are initial signs that the younger generation may be prevailing.
sentences.chinese: 初步迹象显示，年轻一代可能占上风。

sentences.english: At the end of the day, reality will prevail; you can count on it.
sentences.chinese: 最终，现实主义会占上风，你可以信任这种态度。

sentences.english: Do not let anxiousness or frustration take over.
sentences.chinese: 不要让焦虑或沮丧占上风。

definition: on the up/currently winning/rising (in popularity etc)
to predominate/to occupy a dominant position
leeward/downwind/disadvantageous position/to concede or give way in an argument
to be at a disadvantage
to dominate/dominant
lit. two armies have equivalent banners and drums (idiom); fig. evenly matched/roughly comparable (opponents)
evenly matched (idiom)
to cross swords/to have a confrontation (with sb)
to both share the limelight/to both have an equal share of
to draw (a competition)/to fight to a standstill
to pit oneself against sb/to compete with sb/contest/battle/to haggle/to quibble
to suffer a defeat/to fail/to fall behind
slightly better/a cut above
not to know one's place
to fight/to wage war
hard to untie, hard to separate (idiom); inextricably involved/locked in battle
